Usually, we try to use comments only when the code is not explicit enough, or when something unusual happens and you can't name/organize it in a clear way.
For example, the one at line 65 makes sense to me, one can wonder why we are reporting assume, since it is an unusual way to skip tests.
This one seems superfluous to me though, the next line sounds clear enough.

My reasoning behind changing the part being highlighted was, that since it is not in itself problematic to use assumeTrue(...) and only becomes problematic with a constant boolean value, the argument should be part of the highlighted code, given that it is a defining part of the problem. You make a good point, though, in that it could interfere with usability when the argument becomes complex. So generally speaking we rather want to opt for simpler highlights, even if that could mean we potentially don't highlight all parts of the problematic code?

Good point, I agree that the argument is part of the problem, the current situation could be improved.

So generally speaking we rather want to opt for simpler highlights, even if that could mean we potentially don't highlight all parts of the problematic code?

I think we should aim for both (as much as possible..)! To do this, you can use secondary locations. You can have a look at #2914 for an example!
In this case, I would change the message to state that the assume is called with a constant argument and use a secondary location to highlight the argument. The secondary location can still be huge, but it will not be shown when browsing the file, only the main location will be.
Does it make sense to you?
Perfect, that sounds like exactly the fitting solution in this case, thanks!
